Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I stayed at the Porte Doree during the September ‘05 (sorry the review is late). It was fantastic. We liked it much better than the much more expensive 5* hotel we stayed at in London the next week. We had no trouble getting there from the airport on the metro, except for a moment of confusion when we came out the metro exit and didn’t no which way to go in the rather confusing intersection near the hotel. Tip- head to the right of the McDonalds, and it’s on the right side of the street. The first room we were put in was on the second floor and it was quite small and decorated in green. Based on later conversations I can only assume it was meant for one person. We asked to switch and were moved to a very nice room on the top floor (orange). About halfway through the week we got a call from the owner who said that even the room we were currently in was small for two and she would upgrade us to the larger room down the hall for free. It was gorgeous. The bathroom (with separate toilet behind another door) was one of the nicest I have ever stayed in (including the one in London). All of the rooms we saw were very clean and had nice views. We never found them noisy, and all were adequately cool when we opened the windows The wifi access was a bit spotty, but any trouble we had using it could be quickly remedied by calling the front desk. They were cheerful and never failed to fix it. We found the breakfast very reasonable, and best when savoured in bed. Delicious food, beautifully presented, and at your door on demand! We also liked the idea of leaving our key at the desk when we went out, primarily because it meant we were never woken up by the maid. They were never in the way, but very cheerful and thorough. My boyfriend and I both speak enough French to get by, which was helpful, as in the hotel’s neighbourhood there were fewer English speakers than in the city centre. We loved walking around the neighbourhood and found the food delicious and cheap and everyone very friendly (generally, it got less crowded and cheaper the farther we walked from the hotel). We especially recommend the sushi place just down the street from the hotel. The food was delicious and very affordable, and the woman who ran it was lovely. Yes, it is true that the elevator was small (but charming in its own way) but it was more than adequate for the few times we needed to use it and generally we had no problems with the stairs even though we were on the top floor. Although there was no ice maker, the staff were happy to provide a tray on request, which was just fine for chilling a bottle of wine. Could not have asked for more. Wonderful hotel, very clean, very reasonable, impeccable service, and charming atmosphere. An excellent experience in an excellent hotel.

Reviews.Title: “More then a great 2* hotel”
Reviews.Author: lientje
Reviews.Content: We stayed in this hotel last weekend and we loved it! Clean, comfortable, good service and that for a good price! We had a room on the 4th floor at the street side. Although quite noisy with the windows open, it was absolutely quiet when they were closed. I can imagine that this can be a problem on a hot summerday when you want to sleep with the windows open. Yes, you could here the metro rumbling a bit, but it did not bother us at all. It's a big city, after all. We did not use the breakfast at the hotel, but we went to the excellent boulangerie at the other side of the street. Wow, I have never eaten such great croissants! The location and area were great. We did not bother to travel 15-20 minutes by metro to get to the hotel at all. For us it was nice to be able to relax in an area where there are not thousands of tourists walking around. It was also nice to take a walk in the nearby Bois de Vincennes. I would definitively stay here again!

Reviews.Title: “Loved the dorre”
Reviews.Author: koalacub
Reviews.Content: Thanks Christina for running such a wonderful hotel in Paris. Superb location ,about 20 minutes metro ride away from central Paris,with a MacDonalds nearby ,that our son loved. Neighbourhood was great. Your suggestions were most helpful. Hope to visit Paris soon.

Reviews.Title: “Charming small hotel”
Reviews.Author: julie1Scotland
Reviews.Content: This is a charming small hotel a couple of metro rides away from the centre of Paris. Staff were wonderful, very helpful and excellent service. Breakfast delivered to your room (not included in the price we paid by booking direct but only 12 euros) was lovely. Metro across the street which made travelling around very easy. Our room and en-suite bathroom was spacious and I found the rooms and the hotel had lots of character. Would definately stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “A fun experience”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I had an excellent time at this hotel. Even though it is a two-star, the experience and service were definitely excellent. The staff were friendly. The hotel even provides a local guidebook in the room, with restaurant recommendations in French and English. There are fiction books in French and English to borrow and read, and cheap (although slooooww) internet connection in the lobby. The rooms were clean, simple, and very well-kept--not ratty at all. The bathroom looked recently remodeled, had a hairdryer, and the water pressure in the shower was excellent. There's no bathtub, but the shower is adequate--it has the square footage of a standard bathtub, and it's plenty of room. There's no air conditioning, which was no problem in October, but there's a furnace in the room (which I also didn't use), which can be useful on cold days. The location is fine: it's a bit far (about 20-30 mins by metro) from major attractions, but the metro is cheap (especially if you by tickets in a carnet of 10 tickets for 10.70 euros--brings the price down by about thirty cents) and easy to navigate. The Porte Doree area is fine, and it's fun to live in a real French neighborhood after a day of being a tourist. The food nearby is pretty good--I esp. enjoyed the Villa Romano next door (pizza, pasta, seafood), which was fairly cheap (less than 10 euros for a main course), and the Sakura Japanese Restaurant down the street and across the street was also tasty. The Monoprix supermarket is just five minutes away on foot, and has a convenient bakery section. Beware: it (and about half of Paris) is closed on Sundays. The bakery right across the street from the hotel is excellent and tasty, but closed on Mondays and Tuesdays. For food, I strongly recommend bringing a French-English (or French-whatever you speak) dictionary, since many restaurants in the Porte Doree area (and other areas of Paris) speak little English, and the menu gets a bit confusing. I managed to order fine, though, with a bit of guessing. I would definitely go to this hotel again.

Reviews.Title: “Be prepared for noise”
Reviews.Author: Nugsdad_11
Reviews.Content: After booking more than 6 months before arriving we were astounded that our room was not anywhere near our 3 children's room. To add insult to injury our room was so small we hardly had room for our two suitcases. When my wife complained we were offered a ground floor room which was very nice and recently refurbished. All was well until 5.00am the next morning when the traffic noise, Metro and the kitchen and breakfast room next to our walls combined to making sleeping impossible. After 2 days we were able to get our children moved to the same floor as us. However we were unable to move into the very nice room next to them even though it remained empty. Also be aware that the beds are very small doubles, hard and uncomfortable. Altogether a bit of a shame given its great location next to the Metro, and the wonderful park at the end of the street.

Reviews.Title: “Great little hotel”
Reviews.Author: dawnyy23
Reviews.Content: I stayed with my fiance at the Porte Doree at the very end of August, and I was very pleased. We had one of the newly remodeled rooms on the first floor, with a small private terrace. The decor is lovely and I was especially thrilled with the immaculate bathroom. Christina and her staff were friendly and helpful, even accomodating our numerous requests for ice. The neighborhood was great- after long days in the center of Paris doing the tourist thing, it felt like we were coming home each evening. Since the metro is literally right out the door, we didn't find it inconvenient to come back to the hotel to change and get cleaned up before heading out to dinner. No bed bugs, no problems with hot water, and yes, you can hear the metro rumbling, but it didn't bother me at all. Will definitely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “As good as the reviews”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: All the positive things about this hotel including the staff, bakery, closeness of the metro are all correct. I have to say that the breakfast at 7 euros was a bit of rip off (Lipton Tea! Ug!) as was the lack of in room refreshment facilites (kettle, tea, coffee). I was on a budget trip in Europe (Rome, Paris and London) and all the rooms cost about the same but this hotel was the only one to come up short in this respect. I don't know if this is a french thing but to try and sell you a kettle for over 20 euros is tantamount to extorsion. I would recommend this hotel if it is a french problem of a lack of in room refreshments but if it is particular to this hotel I may try elsewhere next time I am in Paris.

Reviews.Title: “A place to call home away from home!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My now fiancé and I stayed at Hotel de la Porte Doree in March of this year. We had an absolutely wonderful experience! Not only was our room darling (#15), but Christina was awesome! During our trip I was going to be alone for a couple days and when I asked Christina for things to do on my own, she was extremely helpful! The morning of our flight my fiancé ran out to the pharmacy for me and when he didn't come back in a timely manner, she came outside to wait with me and make sure everything was okay. Having the Hotel de la Porte Doree to call home on our trip to Paris was really comforting! The street noise people speak of, we really didn't notice, but perhaps we're city people. The metro noise, we noticed, but it sincerely added to the experience. I only hope the Hotel doesn't get TOO popular, because we'd like to stay there on every trip to Paris we make!

Reviews.Title: “Wonderfully welcoming to my partner and me...”
Reviews.Author: RSGracey
Reviews.Content: My partner and I were taking a friend of ours on her first trip ever to Paris, and we picked out this hotel from tripadvisor. It was a joy in every way, but most of all for the open and welcoming reception we got. The moment the American ex-pat receptionist saw us, she suggested that we upgrade our room to a queen-size bed, which turned out to be unbelievably comfortable for a bed-away-from-home. She also told us (seeing that we're both big guys) that we'd be happier with the room's bathtub/shower, as opposed to a tiny cabinet shower in other rooms. Our traveling companion said that the shower in her room was indeed tiny, but that it fit her fine. Our room was well worth the few extra euros per night. The petit dejeuner was delightful and delicious, though the coffee was instant (it still tasted great, and that's par for my French family experience as an exchange student!), and the woman who served us was charming. The weekend deskman was a hoot-n-holler, whose English was excellent, and who was full of stories about the area and about his experiences in Texas. The location is a bit out of the way, but the metro stop is just outside the front door, and so returning each afternoon for a snooze to go back out was no problem at all. DO NOT MISS having dinner at the Bistro de la Port Doree, just around the corner. It's recommended in the hotel guestbook, and it was one of the best meals we had in Paris. Summary: If we had known how lovely it was going to be, we would have scheduled both Paris sections of our vacation (at the beginning and at the end) in this hotel, and we would certainly go back there on our next trip. It's definitely a friendly place for couples of all kinds!

Reviews.Title: “Quaint hotel off the beaten path”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We booked a room here based on previous reviews and were not disappointed. The hotel is right at a metro stop which makes it very convenient to get to all the major tourist attractions in Paris, yet it has a neighborhood feel about it. (For light sleepers, the metro might be a problem, since you can hear it rumble from your room.) The staff were friendly and helpful. They had a room ready for us when we arrived early in the morning. The room was attractive and clean although a bit small with a very small shower. The hotel also had a lift which was the smallest one I have ever encountered -- I found it quaint but some might find it claustrophobic. There is an excellent patisserie down the block as well as a wide assortment of other stores -- including a grocery store and a laundromat. Overall we were very happy with the accomodation. A friendly and attractive place to stay in Paris at a very reasonable cost.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent value but a bit far from the centre of Paris”
Reviews.Author: rep123
Reviews.Content: My family stayed in a triple room with extra bed ( a folding bed) fine for our 12 year old but I wouldn't put anyone older on it. The room was clean and bright and had big windows overlooking the street and bakery where we bought our breakfast each morning. Our daughters loved the narrow lift and insisted on using it every time. We found some places to eat very close to the hotel that had good meals for a reasonable price - check the guide in the room for some good suggestions. The hotel was very close to the metro and it was a great place to stay for the price, however we were there during some very hot weather and it was tiring having to travel in and out of Paris every day, particularly if you wanted to go back at night.

Reviews.Title: “Such a great deal for a great hotel!”
Reviews.Author: newlywed18
Reviews.Content: We spent 3 nights at Hotel Porte de la Doree last month and it was one of the most memorable experiences we had in Paris. Let´s start with the location....it´s near a huge park which is a plus already. There are umpteen grocery stores and fresh fruit stores along with boulangeries (bakeries) around the area. We loved the surroundings and felt completely safe. I used to live in Paris and have seen friends and family stay closer to the Louvre in expensive but crappy hotels, so don´t think that the location isn´t central so the hotel won´t be good either. We got our money´s worth at this hotel. Everything was clean and the towels were changed everyday which was a pleasant surprise at a budget hotel. Everyone was helpful. The room was quite small but we were completely ok with that. The windows opened out to a quiet street on the side. (If you like a lot of privacy, keep your curtains drawn because there are apartments overlooking the hotel.) We left the windows open at night because it was a bit stuffy in the room but closed them early morning because of the noise of the rush hour. Again, not a problem for us. We barely heard anything all night and I´m a light sleeper. I bet it´s perfect in the fall and winter. When we go back to Paris, this is the hotel we´re going to choose again and again.

Reviews.Title: “Also one little problem”
Reviews.Author: urbanfoodie
Reviews.Content: I stayed here in Paris on the last leg of my honeymoon vacation and exclaimed that it looked like the best (of 4 hotels) of what we stayed in throughout our vacation. As I woke up the next morning, my wife said to me "I don't like the looks of this bug on our bed" and when she killed it, it left a large blood stain. That was the first time in my life, I've seen a bedbug. I mentioned it to the man at reception and he was very understanding, moved us to another room and closed off that room. He said it seemed to be a problem on the 3rd floor, we were in room 30 and were switched to 14. Although, we didn't get bitten, and there were no more bug sightings the next night, we decided to switch hotels anyway, for piece of mind. Hope they can cure the problem, it was a really nice hotel otherwise. About the noise... I have to sympathise with others who complain about the noise on the boulevard. I live in downtown Toronto with a streetcar outside my window, and I still haven't heard such noise at all hours of the morning. It seems to come from people speeding along the boulevard at night on Vespas without a proper muffler on their exhaust pipe.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it.”
Reviews.Author: CVOKris
Reviews.Content: Like most everyone else, I thought this hotel was great, and a great value. We really enjoyed staying in an actual Paris neighborhood, rather than in a tourist area. We went everywhere by metro as it was very easy to use and affordable. We also walked between the hotel and the Basitlle area one day, which was fun. We got to go through a farmer's market that was full of locals buying produce and such. The bakery across the street was very good, as was the hotel breakfast. We had the best meal of our trip at the Bistro de la Porte Doree around the corner. A couple things you might be concerned about: the traffic noise does sound loud when the window is open. We found that you could hardly hear it when the window was closed and we didn't need to leave it open while we slept. I would not try to get to and from the airport or train station by metro with your luggage. Take a cab or airport shuttle service for that. Also, be aware that cetain exits from the metro station near the hotel close late at night. You might have to exit across the street from the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Live as a Parisian Would at the Hotel de la Porte Doree”
Reviews.Author: pgatour
Reviews.Content: Bonjour! My mother and I were fortunate to find the Hotel de la Porte Doree for our March 2005 trip to Paris. Thanks to TripAdvisor reviews, we knew we were in for a treat. What a value!!! A few tips & tricks from our lessons learned: GETTING THERE: Finding the hotel is much easier if you have a game plan ahead of time. We simply jumped on various trains and metro lines from CDG -- a mistake, as we were carrying lots of luggage. Instead, take the direct & fast Rossybus to L'Opera, then transfer via the purple line (9?) on the metro to Porte Doree. We took the reverse of this route back to CDG on our last day and found it much easier to navigate. Do take advantage of a Metro Pass during your visit -- you'll need it for all the sightseeing. You can buy the pass at CDG as you fly into Paris. THE ROOM: Although it takes a moment to drop your key at the desk upon leaving and retrieve it later, it's wonderful to know you won't lose it while you're out sightseeing. We used the little lift to send our bags to the second floor, then walked up ourselves. Our room was the perfect size for two women (two twin beds), and the bathroom was indeed immaculate, as other reviewers can attest. (Note: nice bathrooms are a rarity in France, and we were thrilled to have a newly remodeled one in our hotel.) Do bring your own hairdryer and bubble bath for the tub, as they are not provided. The decor was lovely -- very warm and not overly done. Above the beds hung a beautiful print of a mother and daughter, a painting we would soon see in Le Louvre. We were lucky to have great weather and only needed to open our windows (not street-facing, very quiet) for a few moments upon our return to let a little of the cool night air in. THE SERVICE: Christina is a joy. It is, honestly, comforting to hear an American accent once in awhile during an extended trip to Europe. When she is at the desk, you have no worries about easily understanding directions, getting reservations, etc. The night manager is decidedly more difficult to converse with, but he tries very hard to "get" your English and help with whatever questions you might have. The Internet access in the lobby was very useful, and I warmed to it after I wasted precious purchased minutes trying to get into my email account. Note that the keyboard is different, and you shift differently when entering your familiar AOL or MSN password. I was convinced my AOL service had been suspended -- then realized I was simply typing incorrectly! THE NEIGHBORHOOD: The location is amazingly close to a Metro stop. Though some say this is "out of the way" from the main attractions, we would argue that half the fun of being in Paris is experiencing life as a Parisian. It was great to be tourists by day and "locals" by night. Staying in the 12th Arrondisement (sp?) allows you to frequent florists, pharmacies, shoe shops, and grocers you simply could not encounter on the Champs-Elysees and other touristy areas. And, we found the Metro rides to be one of the best ways to learn about the Parisian culture. The people-watching was prime, and we walked off all those pastry pounds by making transfers to various trains. Since so much of the city was covered by foot, it was really kind of relaxing to sit on the Metro for awhile on the way back to the hotel. One word of caution: do not eat on the Metro. Especially if you are American, the French will look at you quizzically. We discovered AFTER our visit that the whole point of the "French Women's Diet" is to savor your food; quickly eating a sandwich and milk on a train simply doesn't fit that standard. Ha! THE FOOD: Speaking of food, the Hotel de la Porte Doree is blessed to be located directly across the street from a fabulous patisserie/boulangerie. If you'd rather not sit for the breakfast in the hotel, you can stop across the street and find a wide assortment of breads and mini-quiches, which the servers will happily warm in a microwave upon request. Then, stop back across the street to the Quick (sp?) fast-food restaurant for a generous serving of orange juice. You can sit outside and people-watch while enjoying your breakfast. We challenge you to avoid the McDonald's two steps away from the hotel. It was, ironically, the only one we saw in Paris. It just wouldn't seem right to order a Big Mac when fresh pastries are available! Need more than a pastry? Though little markets abound, the best place to grocery shop for snacks and food-oriented gifts is the nearby Monoprix (similar to a mini-Meijer). Simply exit the main door of the hotel and make a right. The Monoprix will be a few blocks up, and you can easily tell it's coming because you will see numerous motorbikes and Smart cars parked outside, offset from the street. Bottled water abounds, as does produce, yogurt and cheese. If you simply must have cereal in the mornings, you can find skim & 2% milk there by looking very carefully (the milk selection itself is quite small). Also within walking distance of the hotel are a gas station (an experience in itself), post office (ask Christina or Patrick for directions), numerous optical shops, a Chinese restaurant, Sushi place, Italian restaurant, and many other little finds. Be sure to ask directions to the gardens as well. This will give you a fun look at Parisian apartment-dwelling, and you can take the walkway to the next Metro stop and not have to backtrack. THE LANGUAGE: In our humble opinion, the best part of staying at the Hotel de la Porte Doree is the ability to be immersed in the local culture. Because this is not a touristy area, many of the local shopkeepers speak little/no English. Don't let this scare you. It really helped us improve our French, and it resulted in many fond memories as we did our best to order goods in our own little version of "Franglish combined with sign language." Oh, my! I've written a lot, but the experience deserved to be shared. We hope these hints will help you enjoy the hotel as much as we did! Au revoir & bon voyage!

Reviews.Title: “Excellent value”
Reviews.Author: ayn
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Hotel de la Porte Doree for 5 nights, I chose this hotel base on reviews here. I'm glad I did. The room was large for the price, the staff were friendly and helpful, and the location was very convenient- it's right next to the Porte Doree metro station. Only complaint I have is the spotty WiFi internet connection. Well, I am very glad they provided free wireless access. But the ISP was pretty unreliable. I got great signal strength from my room, but if I used the connection for more than a few minutes it would stop working and I would have to wait a couple of minutes to continue. I'm sure they could just call their ISP and get the problems fixed. If your room faces the street side, it could be quite noisy at night, we were exhausted from the museums and the walking so the noise didn't really bother us much. Street watching from the window was also quite interesting. I would highly recommend this hotel. There was no bugs or any problems like that in our room. I would also highly recommend the small Japanese restaurant across the street, next to the other Metro entrance. Really great sushi and sashimi for very reasonable prices.

Reviews.Title: “Light on the wallet”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Porte Doree in mid June and was surprised at the size of the room for 51 euro it was bigger than I expected. I did not have the breakfast but did by a card for 3 euro to use the computer to get intouch with home. The only down side to the hotel is the street noise. If you are from a big city this won't be that big a deal if not this could be a problem. For me the vibration from the metro which is literally just outside the front door that was a bit of a problem. Also there is no air conditioning so if it is hot out you have to keep a window ajar and then it might be a bit noisy. This is a nice ,clean hotel and the people there are professional. It is best for those on a budget.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice”
Reviews.Author: Johanna_from_Finland
Reviews.Content: I came to Porte Doree because I had read these reviews, and I'm glad I did. My room was perfectly clean and beautifully furnished and decorated. I came to Paris from London where I was staying in a much worse place with a much expensive rate so I was very pleased! I only used the famous poor little lift twice, getting my suitcase up when arriving and then down again - I enjoyed using stairs because of their lovely old-fashioned-style decoration. Everybody I met from the staff was friendly, and the area was ok, seemed to be safe enough for a young single female traveller like me. When I was looking for accommodation before the trip I thought first I should stay in some more central area, but it only takes about 20 minutes to the main sightseeing areas and the metro is easy to use. I took the hotel breakfast once and it was good. I also got once a meal in the Bistro Porte Doree they recommended in the hotel book. It was very delicious and reasonably priced, and there were real Parisians spending their evening in the restaurant, not just tourists. This was my first time in Paris, and when I come back, I will be staying in this hotel again.

Reviews.Title: “Value For Money”
Reviews.Author: fizaalli
Reviews.Content: We stayed in the hotel for 3 days this June during a heatwave - Paris temperature was 29-31 degrees celcius during our days there. The hotel is without air conditioning so the room can become quite hot and stuffy. Worst yet the first night we arrive, they just gave away their last fan away so we have to cope with the heat without fan. Lucky that we originate from a tropical country, so we survived!!! The lesson here is to make sure one ask for a fan as soon as one arrive if one is staying there during the summer months. The room size is adequate, considering that it is in Paris. The location is on the main street, so the noise is quite high, and one can hear the metro from the room. But with the windows closed, all the sounds are muffled -excellent double glazing!!! But if one is sensitive to background noises, than this is not the hotel for them. And of course if the windows have to be closed to muffle the sounds, than the room will become more hot and stuffy. However, the room is clean and they do change the towels daily (I am not sure about the bed linen though). The stuff is not overly helpful, I can only say that the night clerk and the chambermaid are friendly. But then, I did not expect a five star treatment. My husband tried to access the internet wifi but cannot get reliable connection from the room. The monoprix is near - handy place to get ice and mineral water. The area itself is nice with shops and a wide selection of restaurants. For muslims there are 2 halal restaurants nearby. The metro station is nearby, and it takes about 20 minutes ride to major attractions. Be warned that at certain times the metro can be packed, so if one can't bear the metro crowd, then it is best to find a hotel with minimal travelling time using the metro. All that being said, for Euro 64 for double room per night - it is good value for money for a clean hotel, in safe relatively central area with adequate room. Expect some compromise (like Church of Evengelist hymms and prayers event on midsummer day next door etc.) All in all, it is quite an experience staying in the hotel. p/s Have breakfast elsewhere - there are sooooo much choices :)

Reviews.Title: “Lovely hotel”
Reviews.Author: ankie
Reviews.Content: I booked this room after reading the lovely reviews on this site. And it's all true what they say. From the minute you enter the hallway you can feel the charm of the hotel. Our room was beautifull and the staff was very friendly. There is a little flaw I must mention also. We didn't have hot water in the morning but it didn't bother me so much. This was the thirth time I visited Paris but this is by far the best hotel I ever stayed in. I reccomend this to everybode.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Place to Stay in Paris”
Reviews.Author: lippekj
Reviews.Content: My wife, 14 year-old daughter and I just returned from a 2 week stay in Paris at the Hotel de la Porte Doree. The room was clean and much larger than most in Paris. The bathroom was modern even by american standards. The staff was friendly and helpful. The wireless internet service (at no extra cost) was great! It is right on the metro line which makes getting to the sites easy. The only disadvantage, is that being on the outskirts, it takes a little while longer to get to the major sites.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel”
Reviews.Author: RobTor
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Porte Doree from June 6 to 14 and were very pleased with it. I had read all the comments on TripAdvisor and since we had never been to Paris before, I wasn't sure what to expect. Yes, our room was small compared to what we are used to in Canada. But who cares? When you have Paris at your doorstep, you don't spend much time in the room. Our room was on the ground floor, overlooking the street. However, there was a double set of windows and when they were all closed, we couldn't hear any noise from the street. The room was clean and the bathroom had an excellent shower with lots of hot water. Everything looked new, so I think the room had been upgraded fairly recently. The staff were friendly and helpful and the neighbourhood was great. We ate several times at Villa Romana, further along the street. (I recommend their moules marinieres, the freshest mussels I've ever had.) It's a friendly, informal little place and not expensive. (Usually the bill was 40 to 45 euros for the two of us, and that included a bottle of wine.) The neighbourhood has lots of restaurants and a huge park with a lake (Bois de Vincennes). We would definitely stay at Porte Doree again. If you arrive at Charles de Gaulle airport, you'll need 7.85 euros for the train trip into Gare du Nord. Keep your train ticket as you can use it for the subway out to Porte Doree.

Reviews.Title: “tidy and very friendly”
Reviews.Author: Phoebe_bubbles
Reviews.Content: We just got back from our stay in the Porte Doree and loved our time there. Our room was small but perfect for it's purpose...very clean and a very comfortable bed. The Decor is lovely in the Hotel and there are plenty of magazines and books to borrow on each of the landings. We could hear the Metro and the road outside is busy, but it did not keep us awake or ruin the atmosphere... Being so close to the Metro was wonderful, and there are some lovely cafes and bakerys nearby. The booklet writen by the owners had some great suggestions. It was a great base for our trip, and we loved the tiny lift...have never seen anything like it!

Reviews.Title: “Lovely hotel, good price”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We just got back from a two week trip around Europe and we stayed at the Paris hotel for three nights. The rooms were lovely, I must say, especially for the price! The best two star hotel we stayed at in terms of the room itself by far. We were in the triple downstairs, and the beds were the most comfortable we slept on for the entire two weeks. Very roomy as well, with plenty of space for our luggage, etc... The furnishings were beautiful, and the slight odor we smelled upon entering the room (cleaning products maybe?) went away when we opened up the windows and let some fresh air in. We didn't eat breakfast, so I can't help you there (we were tired of croissants by this point). On the down side, there was construction right outside of our window, and if the window was open, workers could have literally stepped inside the room. I understand that the work was necessary but a little bit of notice would have been nice. My mother in law and I were getting undressed with the curtains open and just missed being exposed to a couple of Parisian construction workers! Also, for some reason, I was expecting that since the lady that owned it was an American, we would get a lot of help, etc..., but this was not the case. We were left to fend for ourselves, which turned out to be just fine. There are lots of brochures in the lobby to help you find your way, and a very good map of Paris as well. The subway didn't bother us at all, although we came prepared with earplugs, only my mother in law used them. It just sounded like distant rolling thunder to me. The subway stop is literally right outside the hotel door, but the hotel is out in the suburbs a bit, so expect a 30-40 minute subway ride into town during busy hours. Overall, the hotel was good value for the money, although a bit more customer service would have been appreciated.

Reviews.Title: “Charming and Inexpensive”
Reviews.Author: Nilbo
Reviews.Content: I was astonished to read the review titled "False Impressions", not just because it varied so diametrically from our experience with this hotel, but also because the events described happened at the very same time we were in the hotel. I feel badly that this person had such a negative experience. We checked into Porte Doree on May 24th - the counter person (Jody? An American woman, but not Christina, about whose hospitality I'd heard so much) was delightful, good-natured, and helpful. She showed us the fabled tiny elevator, which - others' complaints aside - we found utterly hilarious and quirky and fun. The room was small by North American standards - but then again, so are the cars, the food portions, the grocery stores ... everything. Because hey, how about that? We weren't in North America. Our rooms - we were a party of five, and took a double and a triple - were scrupulously clean. My wife and I were on the 3rd floor - Room 24, with huge windows that opened onto Rue Daumesnil. Our adult kids were in Room 10, just underneath us on the 2nd. The rooms aren't luxurious, by any means. They are furnished in what can only be described as a utilitarian fashion - two plain chairs, a bed, a ledge/desk. The bathroom was small, and the shower stall comically so - as in "drop the soap, you'd better be able to do a straight-backed knee bend" small. So, sure, not spacious, these rooms. Not the place you'd choose to spend a whole heap of time. But if you go to Paris, can I suggest that you occasionally venture out of your room? There are a couple of things to see in that city, ya know? Why, they got a museum downtown with literally hundreds of dollars worth of art in it. I mean ... DUH. The location is as perfect as you get. Getting around in Paris means becoming acquainted with the Metro, and the entrance to the Metro is 48 steps from the front door of the hotel. No trip to any major attraction took us longer than 25 minutes, even in rush hour. The street itself has tons of excellent restaurants, shops, boulangeries, chocolatiers, brasseries ... this part of Paris is fairly residential and the prices were about 30% less than what you'd pay for a meal on, say, the Champs Elysees. The Italian restaurant we found by going out the front door and turning right, then walking about 40 steps, offered the most stunningly tasty mussel dish I've ever had - for 10 Euros. Please. On the Champs Elysees, the waiter would spill that much worth of wine down the side of your glass. The hotel is not air-conditioned, and the weather when we were there was hot - sometimes oppressively so - but by the time we got back to our room at night it was livable, even comfortable enough to close the windows, which effectively cut out all but the most strident of the city noise. And yes, there was city noise, because - without getting too technical here - PARIS IS A CITY. An exciting, vibrant, alive, bustling, sometimes noisy city, and it's all happening just outside your window and you can choose to embrace that or you can p*ss and moan about it. If you choose the latter, may I suggest Sioux City, North Dakota? It's very quiet. In short, we'd go back to L'Hotel Porte Doree in a heartbeat. I mean, if I win the lottery, then sure, Four Seasons George V here I come. But as long as I want excellent value in one of the most expensive cities on the planet, this is the place I'll go. Feel free to write me for more detail. I travel a lot, and I really liked this place.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect Place to Stay”
Reviews.Author: gephura
Reviews.Content: Hotel de la Porte Doree was ranked #11 when I made my reservations in March. I chose it as the highest ranking hotel in my price range, on the Metro, and with internet access. Since I was going to use the Metro, location was not an issue for me as long as I was within Paris itself. The hotel staff were very nice. Only the desk staff spoke English, housekeeping and kitchen staff did not. The room had two single beds and a full bath and was nice and clean. I felt the breakfast is overpriced for what you got, but then I feel that about all hotels. I personally can get my breakfast at the grocer (apx 3 blocks away), but my traveling companion required fresh coffee. The breakfast was delicious, but if you need more than a croissant, baget, juice, and coffee, you will be dissapointed. The hotel does serves breakfast earlier than other places on the street, the bakeries open between 7 and 8 am, and even McDonald's didn't open until 7 or 7:30am. The internet access was a must for me, you can pay to use the computer in the lobby or get a FREE wireless internet access code. Without the internet access I would have rated this hotel as Above Average. I have noticed that many people complain about the size of the elevators, lack of air contioning, small rooms and street noise when reviewing most European hotels. I am not well traveled, but that seems to be the norm in the places I have stayed in Europe. Europeans (Germans anyway) don't believe in AC. Additionally this hotel, like many, is in an old building, the fact that it has an elevator at all is wonderful. If you don't want to hear street noise, don't go to Paris, most likely your room will overlook the street (ours did, but we were on the 4th floor high up from the worst of it). If you are looking for all of the American amenities of a "Best Western" style hotel, then go to a brand new hotel and spend a lot of money. If you want an affordable place to stay in a nice district with nice staff next to restaurants/grocer/pharmacy/bakery/Metro - then stay here.

Reviews.Title: “FALSE Impressions”
Reviews.Author: madamoiselle
Reviews.Content: I booked this hotel for 5 days via their website only after reading the + reviews on this website. However, I feel like a lot of things are misrepresented and hope that people can use my posting in making their decisions. Was there from May 23rd -May 28th. First the good- hotel beside metro, and some rooms with wifi avalibility. Now the not so good- i'd booked for 5 nights ..and specifically requested a non-smoking room as I'm an asthmatic. Needless to say, after arrival I was put in a smoking room #27 and told there was no option. On the last day was told that I needed to move to another room #34 as I was heading out of the hotel. Didn't help me move and the next room was even worse...and reeked of smoke and alcohol. There were beer bottles under the bed. THe tv didn't work and there was no internet availability. I called the reception and the man there told me he'd be right there. An hour later after having an asthma attack and using my albuterol inhaler twice I went downstairs and requested that he please come check my room. He took his time, while I sat out of breath in the hallway of the floor. Once he came upstairs he said that there was nothing he could do, I requested that I please be moved to some other room as I couldn't breathe. Was told the hotel was full. Finally, upset and sick I told him I was leaving and started calling other facilities. 15mins later he came to show me some other rooms where I might be moved...all worse than the last one. Finally, when he saw me wheezing and huffing he showed me room #37 (non smoking room). I took it because I was exhausted from climbing up and down the floors. What I want to know is why I wasn't given the room to begin with?? Was it because I was young and they figured I had no option in a foreign country. Also there is no breakfast included in your hotel stay. If you would like breakfast you have to order the night before and it is 6 euros for 1 croissant, 1 cup of orange jucie,& 1 packet of jelly. I'd highly recommend going out and actually having a real breakfast at the little cafes around. There is a MONOPRIX 10 minutes down the road...a walmart/ target like store, and you can buy fresh croissants, juice, groceries, beauty,etc there. Also there is NO Airconditioning, which is a very severe drawback for the summers because the heat was sweltering. And keeping the windows open is even worse because you hear ambulances, police cars and the metro rushing by every 5 minutes. For light sleepers the tremors from the metro every 5 minutes can be problem. The last & worst problem was the plumbing...the toilet constantly smelled like a urinal even after the cleaning service went thru the room. The sink starts accumulating water after you flush ...& the water smells like the sewer at that point. The celing also had paint chipping and falling...I'll try and post some pictures of that too. Lastly, please don't use their SAFE. I had my passport put in it...and not everyone has the key. And there was a whole scene to get my passport back because I hadn't requested it back on wednesday 25th may...after which the safe was locked with my passport and the owners left with the key ...to the United States. However, I will say there was an american receptionist(JODY) who was there one day .. really helped me in getting my passport back.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel! Great Location!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We booked this hotel strictly from Trip Advisor's rating and were not disappointed! The location is great - you can see the Metro station from the doorstep. It is more like a bed and breakfast than a hotel. There's a computer in the lobby so you can email back home. A great price for Paris with a nice bathroom/shower right in your room. With the subway (metro) right beside you, who needs to pay 5 times as much in order to be in the center of town? I would definitely stay here again. Our room looked right out onto the street and when we shut the windows there was QUIET. Amazing soundproof windows! Highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: “Safe neighbourhood, convenient location”
Reviews.Author: stinkingdoufu
Reviews.Content: Good things to know: - There are a couple of bakeries, fast food resto's, and restuarants all within 100 metres of the hotel - The subway is 30 metres from the hotel - The coulee verte, an old railroad transformed into a walking path is about 150 metres from the hotel. It ends at the Bastille, is 4.5 K long, car free and perfect for a run or stroll. - Its a safe residential neigbourhood, though parking is not easy to find. Apparantly a parking ticket is 11 or 13 euro, so better not to pay for a parking card, since a parking card costs 10 euro, with a max parking time of 2 hrs. - We visited the marche d'aligre, the Bercy park, and the Cour St- Emilion, all in the 12th district of paris. - The hotel is very clean, nice room, though not very spacious, with a very helpful and kind front desk manager(/owner?)

Reviews.Title: “Simply loved the Porte Doree!”
Reviews.Author: rachelbsn
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Porte Doree and truly enjoyed it. The bathroom was nice and the room quaint. We liked the convenience of the hotel to the Metro and the bakery across the street is simply magnificent! The staff was friendly and helpful. I've read some of the poor reviews and was quite surprised at the complaints. I didn't feel/hear the Metro, nor did I have a problem with a smokey smell. As for the noise, it is a city, which adds to the charm. I actually enjoyed being awakened with the sounds of Parisians starting their morning. The hotel made me feel like I was secretly watching the residents' lives, and I feel fortunate to have had the opportunity to see how they actually live. If you're wanting a true taste of Paris, avoid the touristy neighborhoods, which are only out to make a buck (or euro). Stay at the Porte Doree!

HotelInfo.Name: Hotel de la Porte Doree
HotelInfo.Address: 273 ave Daumesnil | 12 Arr., 75012 Paris, France
